grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para ações habituais, fatos gerais, verdades universais e rotinas. Estrutura: sujeito + verbo (base form, acrescenta -s ou -es na 3ª pessoa singular). Também usado em instruções, manchetes e para eventos futuros programados (e.g. 'The train leaves at 8').
rules: I/You/We/They + base form of verb (Ex: I work)
He/She/It + base form + 's' or 'es'(ex: He works, She watches)
Use 'do/does' for questions and negatives
examples: I work every day
She studies English
They don't like coffee

grammarTopics.explanation: Wh Questions são usadas para obter informações específicas. Começam com palavras interrogativas como what, where, when, who, why e how. No Present Simple, usamos 'do/does' antes do sujeito.
rules: Wh word + do + I/you/we/they + base verb (Ex: Where do you live?)
Wh word + does + he/she/it + base verb (Ex: Where does she live?)
Use base form of the verb after do/does
For 'who' as subject, do/does is not necessary (Ex: Who called you?)
examples: Where do you live?
What does she study?
Why do they wake up early?
How do you go to school?
Who plays the guitar?

grammarTopics.explanation: O verbo 'to be' (ser/estar) é usado para identificar pessoas, coisas, lugares, estados, nacionalidades, profissões, etc. Sua forma varia de acordo com o sujeito.
rules: I → am ('m)
You/We/They → are ('re)
He/She/It → is ('s)
examples: I am/I'm a student.
She is/She's from Brazil.
They are/They're happy.

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para ações que estão acontecendo agora, situações temporárias e planos futuros próximos. Estrutura: sujeito + am/is/are + verbo com -ing.
rules: I am + verb-ing
He/She/It is + verb-ing
You/We/They are + verb-ing
examples: I am reading a book now
She is watching TV at the moment
They are playing football right now

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para ações concluídas em um tempo definido no passado. Estrutura: sujeito + verbo no passado simples (regular ou irregular). (ex: I worked, She went)
rules: Regular verbs: verb + 'ed'
Irregular verbs tem formas especiais (ex: go -> went, have -> had)
Use 'did' for questions and negatives
Não é usado para conectar passado ao presente; nesse caso, usa-se Present Perfect.
examples: I worked yesterday
She went to Paris last year
They didn't come to the party

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para descrever ações em progresso em um momento específico do passado ou ações interrompidas por outra. Estrutura: sujeito + was/were + verbo com -ing. (ex: I was reading when he called.)
rules: I/He/She/It was + verb-ing (e.g., He was reading)
You/We/They were + verb-ing (e.g., They were playing)
Often used with 'when' or 'while' for interrupted actions
examples: I was watching TV when you called
They were studying at 8 PM yesterday
She was cooking while he was cleaning

grammarTopics.topic: There is/There are - Present and Past
grammarTopics.explanation: 'There is' (singular) e 'There are' (plural) são usados para indicar a existência de algo no presente. 'There was' (singular) e 'There were' (plural) são usados para o passado.
rules: Presente: There is (há) → para singular / There are (há) → para plural
Passado: There was (havia) → para singular / There were (haviam) → para plural
Forma negativa: There isn't/aren't (presente) / There wasn't/weren't (passado)
Perguntas: Is there?/Are there? (presente) / Was there?/Were there? (passado)
examples: There is a book on the table.
There are many students in the class.
There was a party yesterday.
There were three cars in the garage.

grammarTopics.topic: Indefinite Pronouns: Something, Anything, Nothing, Everything, etc...
grammarTopics.explanation: Pronomes indefinidos são usados para se referir a pessoas, coisas ou lugares de forma não específica. São divididos em três categorias: coisas (thing), pessoas (one/body) e lugares (where). Usamos 'some' em frases afirmativas, 'any' em negativas e interrogativas, e 'no' para negação.
rules: Something (alguma coisa) – frases afirmativas
Anything (alguma coisa, nenhuma coisa) – frases negativas e interrogativas
Nothing (nada) – significa 'not anything'
Everything (tudo) – todas as coisas
Someone/Somebody (alguém) – frases afirmativas
Anyone/Anybody (alguém, ninguém) – negativas e interrogativas
No one/Nobody (ninguém)
Everyone/Everybody (todo mundo)
Somewhere (em algum lugar) – afirmativas
Anywhere (em algum lugar, em lugar nenhum) – negativas e interrogativas
Nowhere (em lugar nenhum)
Everywhere (em todo lugar)
examples: I want something to eat.
Is there anything I can do?
There is nothing in the box.
She knows everything about math.
Someone is at the door.
Did anyone call me?
No one came to the party.
Everyone loves pizza.
Let's go somewhere quiet.
I can't find my keys anywhere.
There is nowhere to sit.
We looked everywhere for the cat.

grammarTopics.topic: Countable and Uncountable Nouns with a/an, some, any
grammarTopics.explanation: Countable nouns podem ser contados e têm forma singular e plural. Uncountable nouns não podem ser contados e só têm forma singular. Usamos 'a/an' com countable singular, 'some' em frases afirmativas e 'any' em negativas e perguntas.
rules: A/AN: usado com countable nouns no singular
SOME: usado em frases afirmativas com countable plural e uncountable nouns
ANY: usado em frases negativas e perguntas com countable plural e uncountable nouns
Uncountable nouns: não usamos a/an, não têm forma plural
examples: I need a book. (countable singular)
I need some books. (countable plural)
I need some water. (uncountable)
I don't have any money. (negative)
Do you have any questions? (question)

grammarTopics.explanation: Subject pronouns (I, you, he, etc.) substituem substantivos como sujeito da frase. Possessive adjectives (my, your, his, etc.) indicam posse e sempre vêm antes de um substantivo.
rules: I → my
You → your
He → his
She → her
It → its
We → our
They → their
examples: I love my family.
She is doing her homework.
They have their books.

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para conectar passado e presente: experiências de vida, ações que começaram no passado e continuam no presente, ou ações passadas com efeito no presente. Estrutura: sujeito + have/has + particípio passado (ex: I have eaten).
rules: I/You/We/They have + past participle
He/She/It has + past participle
Geralmente utilizado com 'ever', 'never', 'already', 'yet'
Não se usa com expressões de tempo terminado (yesterday, last year, in 2010). Nestes casos, usa-se Past Simple.
examples: I have visited Paris three times
She has already finished her work
They haven't seen that movie yet

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para enfatizar a duração de uma ação que começou no passado e ainda continua, ou cujos efeitos ainda são visíveis. Estrutura: sujeito + have/has + been + verbo com -ing ou a forma contraída: (ex: I have been studying ou I've been studying).
rules: I/You/We/They have been + verb-ing. (e.g., I have been studying)
He/She/It has been + verb-ing. (e.g., She has been working)
Geralmente utilizado com 'for' ou 'since'
examples: I have been studying English for five years
She has been working here since 2010
They have been waiting for over an hour

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para indicar uma ação que aconteceu antes de outra ação no passado. Estrutura: sujeito + had + particípio passado. (ex: I had eaten before he arrived).
rules: Had + past participle for all subjects (e.g., I had eaten, She had gone)
Often used in reported speech and conditional sentences
Não é necessário se a ordem dos eventos já estiver clara. É mais comum em escrita formal e narrativa.
examples: When I arrived, she had already left
They had finished dinner before I got home
He told me he had seen the movie

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para enfatizar a duração de uma ação que estava acontecendo antes de outra no passado. Estrutura: sujeito + had been + verbo com -ing.(ex: I had been studying for two hours when he arrived).
rules: Had been + verb-ing for all subjects (e.g., I had been studying, She had been working)
Often used with 'for' or 'since' to indicate duration
Mais raro na fala cotidiana; usado em narrativas para dar ênfase a tempo/duração.
examples: I had been studying for two hours when you called
She had been working there for five years when she quit
They had been waiting for over an hour when the bus finally arrived

grammarTopics.explanation: Usamos 'will + base form' para fazer previsões, promessas, ou decisões espontâneas sobre o futuro. (ex: I will call you later).
rules: Will + base form for all subjects (e.g., I will go, She will see)
Usa-se 'will not' ou 'won't' para negativas (e.g., I won't go)
‘Will’ não se usa para planos já decididos (usa-se 'going to' nesses casos)
examples: I will help you with your homework. (decisão espontânea)
It will rain tomorrow. (previsão)
I will always support you. (promessa)
I will carry your bag for you. (oferta)

grammarTopics.explanation: Usa-se 'am/is/are going to + base form'  para planos ou previsões baseadas em evidências (ex: Look at those dark clouds. It's going to rain).
rules: I am going to + base form (ex: I am going to study)
He/She/It is going to + base form (ex: She is going to travel)
You/We/They are going to + base form (ex: They are going to buy a house)
‘going to’ não se usa para horários fixos (usa-se Present Simple ou Present Continuous).(ex: The train leaves at 6 PM)
examples: I am going to visit my parents next week
She is going to study medicine
They are going to buy a new car

grammarTopics.explanation: Use 'will be + verb-ing' to talk about actions that will be in progress at a specific time in the future.
rules: Will be + verb-ing for all subjects
Often used with time expressions like 'at this time tomorrow'
examples: This time tomorrow, I will be flying to Paris
At 8 PM tonight, she will be studying for her exam
They will be waiting for you at the airport

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para ações que terão sido concluídas antes de um momento específico no futuro. Estrutura: sujeito + will have + particípio passado.
rules: Will have + past participle for all subjects (e.g., I will have finished, She will have seen)
normalmente utilizado com 'by' or 'by the time'(ex: By next year, I will have graduated)
Mais usado em escrita formal, raramente em conversas informais.
examples: By next year, I will have graduated
By the time you arrive, she will have finished cooking
They will have completed the project by Friday

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para enfatizar a duração de uma ação até certo ponto no futuro. Estrutura: sujeito + will have been + verbo com -ing.(ex: By next month, I will have been working here for five years).
rules: Will have been + verb-ing for all subjects (e.g., I will have been working, She will have been studying)
Geralmente utilizado com 'for' para indicar duração (ex: for five years) e 'by' para indicar o ponto no futuro (ex: by next month)
Pouco comum em conversas cotidianas; aparece mais em contextos formais ou acadêmicos.
examples: By next month, I will have been working here for five years
By 2025, she will have been studying English for ten years
They will have been traveling for six months by the time they return

grammarTopics.explanation: Usa-se Zero conditional para verdades gerais (if + presente, presente) ex:(If you heat water, it boils) e First conditional: para possibilidades reais no futuro (if + presente, will + forma base).(ex: If it rains, we will stay home). 'Unless' significa 'if not' (ex: Unless you study, you won't pass the exam).
rules: Zero conditional: If + present simple, present simple (para fatos gerais e verdades universais ex: If you heat water, it boils)
First conditional: If + present simple, will + base form (para situações futuras possíveis ex: If it rains, we will stay home)
Use 'unless' instead of 'if not'(ex: Unless you study, you won't pass the exam)
examples: If you heat ice, it melts (zero conditional)
If it rains, we will stay home (first conditional)
Unless you study, you won't pass the exam

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para situações hipotéticas ou irreais no presente ou futuro. Estrutura: If + passado simples, would + forma base. (ex: If I were rich, I would travel the world). 'Were' é usado em vez de 'was' para todos os sujeitos em inglês formal. Frequentemente usado para dar conselhos.
rules: If + past simple, would + base form (e.g., If I were, I would go)
Use 'were' instead of 'was' for all subjects in formal English (e.g., If he were, If I were)
Often used to give advice (e.g., If I were you, I would...)
examples: If I had more time, I would learn French
If she were here, she would know what to do
I would travel the world if I won the lottery

grammarTopics.explanation: Usado para situações hipotéticas no passado, expressando arrependimento ou críticas. Estrutura: If + past perfect, would have + past participle. (ex: If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam).
rules: If + past perfect, would have + past participle (e.g., If I had known, I would have gone)
Used to express regret or criticism about past events (e.g., If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam)
Pode também ser usado 'could have' ou 'might have' instead of 'would have' para indicar possibilidade ou habilidade (e.g., If she had tried, she could have succeeded)
examples: If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam
She would have come if she had known about the party
If they had left earlier, they wouldn't have missed the flight

grammarTopics.explanation: Mix different conditional forms to talk about hypothetical situations where the time in the if-clause is different from the time in the main clause.
rules: If + past perfect, would + base form (past condition, present result)
If + past simple, would have + past participle (present condition, past result)
examples: If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam. (situação irreal no passado)
If they had left earlier, they would have caught the train. (oportunidade perdida no passado)
If I were you, I would take that job. (conselho no presente)
If she were more organized, she would have finished the project on time. (situação irreal no presente)
If he had listened to my advice, he wouldn't be in trouble now (past condition, present result)
If she wasn't so busy, she would have helped us yesterday (present condition, past result)

grammarTopics.explanation: Usada para dar ênfase à ação em vez do sujeito. Estrutura: sujeito + verbo to be (em tempo adequado) + particípio passado. (ex: The book was written by Shakespeare).
rules: Present simple: am/is/are + past participle (e.g., is written)
Past simple: was/were + past participle (e.g., was written)
Present perfect: have/has been + past participle (e.g., has been written)
O agente da ação pode ser incluído usando 'by' (e.g., The book was written by Shakespeare)
examples: The cake was eaten by the children. (ação passada, foco no bolo)
The project is being managed by a new team. (ação presente contínua, foco no projeto)
The reports have been completed by the team. (ação presente perfeita, foco nos relatórios)
The house is cleaned every day. (ação habitual, foco na casa)
The letters were sent yesterday. (ação passada, foco nas cartas)

grammarTopics.topic: Quantifiers: Much, many, a lot of, a little, a few
grammarTopics.explanation: Usamos 'many' com countable nouns (plural), 'much' com uncountable nouns, 'a lot of' com ambos, 'a few' com countable nouns (pequena quantidade), e 'a little' com uncountable nouns (pequena quantidade).
rules: Many → countable nouns plural (many books)
Much → uncountable nouns (much water)
A lot of → countable plural e uncountable (afirmativas)
A few → countable nouns plural (pequena quantidade)
A little → uncountable nouns (pequena quantidade)
examples: I have many friends. (countable plural)
We don't have much time. (uncountable)
She has a lot of books. (countable plural)
I need a little help. (uncountable small quantity)
There are a few apples. (countable plural small quantity)

grammarTopics.explanation: Usamos comparativos para comparar duas coisas (mais/menos) e superlativos para comparar três ou mais coisas (o mais/o menos).
rules: Comparativo: adjective + -er + than (short adjectives) / more + adjective + than (long adjectives)
Superlativo: the + adjective + -est (short adjectives) / the most + adjective (long adjectives)
Irregulares: good → better → the best, bad → worse → the worst, far → farther → the farthest
CVC: dobra consoante final (big → bigger → the biggest)
Terminados em -y: y → i (happy → happier → the happiest)
examples: John is taller than Mary. (comparative)
John is the tallest in the class. (superlative)
This is more interesting than that. (comparative)
This is the most interesting book. (superlative)

grammarTopics.explanation: Modal verbs são verbos auxiliares usados para expressar habilidade, possibilidade, permissão, obrigação, necessidade, probabilidade, hipóteses ou atitudes do falante. Eles são sempre seguidos pelo verbo na forma base (sem 'to'). Cada modal tem usos específicos. são eles: (can, could, may, might, must, shall, should, will, would)
rules: Modal verbs não mudam de forma (não existe 'to can' ou 'cans'). Não recebem -s na 3ª pessoa do singular. Para expressar passado ou aspectos mais específicos, usam-se construções como 'could' (passado de can), 'should have + particípio' (aconselhamento no passado), 'must have + particípio' (dedução no passado). Alguns modais são pouco usados em contextos informais, como 'shall'.
Can: habilidade, permissão, possibilidade (e.g., I can swim)
Could: habilidade no passado, possibilidade, pedido educado (e.g., She could speak French when she was young)
May: permissão formal, possibilidade (e.g., May I leave early?)
Might: possibilidade (e.g., It might rain later)
Must: obrigação, dedução (e.g., You must wear a seatbelt)
Shall: sugestão, oferta (formal) (e.g., Shall we dance?)
Should: conselho, expectativa (e.g., You should see a doctor)
Will: futuro, vontade, promessa (e.g., I will help you)
Would: pedido educado, hipótese (e.g., Would you like some coffee?)
examples: I can speak English. (habilidade)
You must wear a seatbelt. (obrigação)
She might come to the party. (possibilidade)
May I leave early? (permissão)
You should see a doctor. (conselho)
He will help you with your homework. (futuro)
If I were you, I would take that job. (hipótese)
Could you please pass the salt? (pedido educado)
They must be at home; the lights are on. (dedução)
Shall we go for a walk? (sugestão)
She could play the piano when she was five. (habilidade no passado)
You should have called me earlier. (conselho no passado)
He must have forgotten the meeting. (dedução no passado)

grammarTopics.explanation: Orações subordinadas que identificam ou dão informações extras sobre um substantivo. Usam pronomes relativos: who (pessoas), which (coisas/animais), that (pessoas/coisas), whose (posse), where (lugares), when (tempo). Podem ser defining (essenciais) ou non-defining (adicionais, entre vírgulas).
rules: That' não pode ser usado em non-defining clauses. Em defining clauses, o pronome relativo pode ser omitido se for o objeto da oração (ex: 'The book (that) I read was great').
Use 'who' para pessoas, 'which' para coisas/animais, 'that' para ambos (em defining clauses), 'whose' para posse, 'where' para lugares, 'when' para tempo.
Defining clauses give essential information (no commas)
Non-defining clauses give extra information (use commas)
O pronome relativo pode ser omitido se for o objeto da oração na defining clause
examples: The man who called you is my uncle. (pessoa)
The dog which barked all night kept me awake. (coisa/animal)
The movie that we watched was amazing. (defining clause, pessoa ou coisa)
I met a writer whose books I love. (posse)
This is the park where I play football. (lugar)
I remember the day when we first met. (tempo)
My brother, who lives in New York, is visiting us next week. (non-defining clause)
The Eiffel Tower, which is in Paris, is a famous landmark. (non-defining clause)
The car that he bought last year is already broken. (defining clause)
